reviewText:
The tactics involved in playing this game are layered endlessly. If NF has reason to believe you might be heading for straight for railgun heavies, you should respond with a light tank or APC rush early game (unless they are expecting you to, of course). Commanding actual players is extremely challenging but endlessly rewarding. Much like Age of Empires II, the gameplay does not reach any sort of nash-equilibria because the real bottleneck is your own ability to keep track of everything at once.

For the soldiers on the ground, the game is totally different. The tactical challenge lies is choosing your class, or the loadout of your tank, and in making sure that the decisions of the team as a whole make sense, and that nobody is missing some sneaky enemy tactic. The constant challenge otherwise is of course, to aim and respond, using cover to keep yourself alive while gaining ground on the enemy. All of the guns respond decently, but you'll find your preferences - I love the sniper and pistol, but many prefer the shotguns. Fortunately none of them are so overpowered that they become the only choice.

Unfortunately, although there are many players, most of the time none of them are playing at all. That's why you will see many people arguing over whether the game is dead" or not. See for yourself with the steam charts tracker[steamcharts.com]

An excellent squad based shooter mixed with RTS elements. One player becomes the commander, researching techs for better equipment and vehicles, managing resouces, building pre-set vehicles for faster construction, setting waypoints for ground units and helping to protect the main base. Meanwhile, players on the ground build the projects set by the commander and defend valuable buildings such as barracks and vehicle depots. Combat, for the most part, if fun and challenging with multiple classes and multiple guns for each class. Anti-Armor classes, Base Infantry, and Medics keep pressure on the front line while Engineers contruct turrets and keep bases and resource collectors safe. Sniping is perhaps the most difficult, and yet the most rewarding, since the maps are so large, sniping is a real challenge, but can turn the tide of battles.  As for faults, graphical fidelity is rather low with any given map's group texture being the same texture streched across miles, finally, many maps feature long and dull tracts of land that brings about boring combat. However, despite these few gripes, Empires is an excellent game with many facets that has kept me playing.

Hands down best concept! The equation we're talking about here is equivalent to Red Alert x Battlefield x Half Life 2, which theoretically should = quite a fantastic gaming experience! The commander's options take time to learn to get used to. As reacting quickly and getting together all of the right research upgrades to meet the preference of your men is deemed 'taskworthy'. I wouldn't say the multi-tasking is comparable to the difficulty of a well-known strategy game such as StarCraft 2, unless you can consider particular FPS gameplay types as 'strategic'. This mod is a game which holds a completely magnificent and unique genre all to its own. Recommend this to all your friends and get a team together! See you on the battlefield!

I am never left unimpressed by the things the modding community dreams up.
Empires is a well made FPS/RTS with very well made maps, and a well structured open battlefield type gameplay that makes vehicles an integral yet welcome addition to the accomodating maps, while for the most part still leaving a decent amount of gameplay options for the guy who still just wants to run and gun.

The RTS aspect is of a single force commander within a mobile command vehicle. this immediately sets a need for communication and cooperation, as the commander can only establish buildings with the help of his soldiers,

who are playing the game from an FPS point of view and are completing objectives all in real time.  It provides a very true to life aspect to  battlefield tactics that many are sure to enjoy. The perks system is somewhat rudimentary but still rewarding, and the entire game has a pleasant steampunky feel to it, even providing snippets of a seemingly well thought out backstory.
